clusters.title: Time is running out for SpaceX to make a splash with second-gen Starship
clusters.neutral_headline: SpaceX Faces Time Pressure for Second-Gen Starship Launch

items.title: Time is running out for SpaceX to make a splash with second-gen Starship
items.standfirst: SpaceX is gearing up for another Starship launch after three straight disappointing test flights.
items.content: STARBASE, Texas—A beehive of aerospace technicians, construction workers, and spaceflight fans descended on South Texas this weekend in advance of the next test flight of SpaceX's gigantic Starship rocket, the largest vehicle of its kind ever built. Towering 404 feet (123.1 meters) tall, the rocket will lift off during a one-hour launch window beginning at 6:30 pm CDT (7:30 pm EDT; 23:30 UTC) Sunday. The main concern for Sunday's launch attempt will be weather conditions at Starbase, located a few miles north of the US-Mexico border. There's just a 45 percent chance of favorable weather for liftoff Sunday, according to SpaceX. It will take about 66 minutes for the rocket to travel from the launch pad in Texas to a splashdown zone in the Indian Ocean northwest of Australia. You can watch the test flight live on SpaceX's official website. We've also embedded a live stream from Spaceflight Now and LabPadre below.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: SpaceX is preparing for another Starship launch.
The company has experienced three disappointing test flights.
Time is running out for SpaceX to make progress.
The second-generation Starship is the focus.
The launch is crucial for SpaceX's goals.

clusters.title: An inner-speech decoder reveals some mental privacy issues
clusters.neutral_headline: An inner-speech decoder reveals some mental privacy issues: Words you'll never speak still cause activity in the brain's speech centers

items.title: An inner-speech decoder reveals some mental privacy issues
items.standfirst: Words you'll never speak still cause activity in the brain's speech centers.
items.content: Most experimental brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) that have been used for synthesizing human speech have been implanted in the areas of the brain that translate the intention to speak into the muscle actions that produce it. A patient has to physically attempt to speak to make these implants work, which is tiresome for severely paralyzed people. To go around it, researchers at the Stanford University built a BCI that could decode inner speech—the kind we engage in silent reading and use for all our internal monologues. The problem is that those inner monologues often involve stuff we don’t want others to hear. To keep their BCI from spilling the patients’ most private thoughts, the researchers designed a first-of-its-kind “mental privacy” safeguard. Overlapping signals The reason nearly all neural prostheses used for speech are designed to decode attempted speech is that our first idea was to try the same thing we did with controlling artificial limbs: record from the area of the brain responsible for controlling muscles. “Attempted movements produced very strong signal, and we thought it could also be used for speech,” says Benyamin Meschede Abramovich Krasa, a neuroscientist at Stanford University who, along with Erin M. Kunz, was a co-lead author of the study.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: An inner-speech decoder has revealed privacy concerns.
The decoder can detect brain activity related to speech.
Even unspoken words cause activity in speech centers.
This raises questions about mental privacy.
The research explores the intersection of brain activity and privacy.

clusters.title: Why wind farms attract so much misinformation and conspiracy theory
clusters.neutral_headline: Wind farms face misinformation and conspiracy theories

items.title: Why wind farms attract so much misinformation and conspiracy theory
items.standfirst: If you think climate change is a hoax, you might believe wind turbines poison groundwater.
items.content: When Donald Trump recently claimed, during what was supposed to be a press conference about a European Union trade deal, that wind turbines were a "con job" that drive whales "loco," kill birds and even people, he wasn’t just repeating old myths. He was tapping into a global pattern of conspiracy theories around renewable energy—particularly wind farms. (Trump calls them “windmills”—a climate denier trope.) Like 19th century fears that telephones would spread diseases, wind farm conspiracy theories reflect deeper anxieties about change. They combine distrust of government, nostalgia for the fossil fuel era, and a resistance to confronting the complexities of the modern world. And research shows that, once these fears are embedded in someone’s worldview, no amount of fact-checking is likely to shift them.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Some believe wind turbines poison groundwater, fueled by climate change denial.
Misinformation targets wind farms, often linked to broader conspiracy theories.
The article explores the spread of false information about wind energy.
It examines the motivations behind these beliefs and their impact.
The piece highlights the challenges of combating misinformation in this context.

clusters.title: College student’s “time travel” AI experiment accidentally outputs real 1834 history
clusters.neutral_headline: AI experiment outputs real 1834 history unexpectedly

items.title: College student’s “time travel” AI experiment accidentally outputs real 1834 history
items.standfirst: Hobbyist training AI on Victorian texts gets an unexpected history lesson from his own creation.
items.content: A hobbyist developer building AI language models that speak Victorian-era English "just for fun" got an unexpected history lesson this week when his latest creation mentioned real protests from 1834 London—events the developer didn't know had actually happened until he Googled them. "I was interested to see if a protest had actually occurred in 1834 London and it really did happen," wrote Reddit user Hayk Grigorian, who is a computer science student at Muhlenberg College in Pennsylvania. For the past month, Grigorian has been developing what he calls TimeCapsuleLLM, a small AI language model (like a pint-sized distant cousin to ChatGPT) which has been trained entirely on texts from 1800–1875 London. Grigorian wants to capture an authentic Victorian voice in the AI model's outputs. As a result, the AI model ends up spitting out text that's heavy with biblical references and period-appropriate rhetorical excess.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: A college student's AI project generated historical data from Victorian texts.
The AI unexpectedly produced accurate historical information from 1834.
The student was training the AI on Victorian literature.
The AI's output provided an unexpected history lesson.
The project highlights the potential for AI to uncover historical insights.

clusters.title: Two men fell gravely ill last year; their infections link to deaths in the ’80s
clusters.neutral_headline: Infections link to deaths from the 1980s

items.title: Two men fell gravely ill last year; their infections link to deaths in the ’80s
items.standfirst: The bacterium is known to live in Mississippi, but the new cases may expand its range.
items.content: Four men in Georgia, all living in the same county, mysteriously became infected with a potentially deadly soil bacterium that's normally found in the tropics and subtropics, particularly Southeast Asia and northern Australia. The four cases were tied together not just by their shared location but also by the bacterial strain; whole genome sequencing showed the bacteria causing all four infections were highly related, suggesting a shared source of their infections. But this bacterium doesn't tend to jump from person to person. And none of the men had recent travel that explained the infection. In fact, only one of the men had ever been to a place where the bacterium lives, but it was decades before his infection. And there's another twist: The four infections spanned decades. The first occurred in 1983, the second in 1989, and the last two occurred a day apart in September 2024. In a newly published study in Emerging Infectious Diseases, state and federal health researchers suggest that the four linked cases indicate that the dangerous bacterium—Burkholderia pseudomallei—has been lurking in the Georgia area the entire time. They also think they know what triggered its recent reemergence: Hurricane Helene.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Two men fell ill last year with infections linked to deaths from the 1980s.
The bacterium causing the infections is known to live in Mississippi.
The new cases may expand the bacterium's known geographic range.
The article explores the connection between the recent illnesses and past deaths.
It investigates the potential spread of the bacterium.

clusters.title: Trump says US will take 10% stake in Intel because CEO wants to “keep his job”
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump says US will take 10% stake in Intel

items.title: Trump says US will take 10% stake in Intel because CEO wants to “keep his job”
items.standfirst: Intel deal could pave the way for the US to profit off CHIPS Act funding.
items.content: Intel has agreed to sell the US a 10 percent stake in the company, Donald Trump announced at a news conference Friday. The US stake is worth $10 billion, Trump said, confirming that the deal was inked following his talks with Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan. Trump had previously called for Tan to resign, accusing the CEO of having "concerning" ties to the Chinese Communist Party. During their meeting, the president claimed that Tan "walked in wanting to keep his job and he ended up giving us $10 billion for the United States."Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Trump stated the US will acquire a 10% stake in Intel.
The move is reportedly due to the CEO's desire to keep his job.
The deal could allow the US to profit from CHIPS Act funding.
The article discusses the political and financial implications of the deal.
It examines the potential benefits for both the US and Intel.

clusters.title: Developer gets 4 years for activating network “kill switch” to avenge his firing
clusters.neutral_headline: Developer gets four years for activating network kill switch

items.title: Developer gets 4 years for activating network “kill switch” to avenge his firing
items.standfirst: Disgruntled developer was caught after naming the "kill switch" after himself.
items.content: A disgruntled developer has been sentenced to four years in prison after building a "kill switch" that locked all users out of a US firm's network the moment that his name was deleted from the company directory following his termination. Davis Lu, a 55-year-old Chinese national residing in Houston, was convicted of "causing intentional damage to protected computers" in March, the US Department of Justice said in a press release announcing his sentencing Thursday. Lu had worked at Eaton Corp. for approximately 11 years when suddenly the company reduced his responsibilities during a 2018 "realignment." Anticipating his termination was imminent, Lu began planting different forms of malicious code.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: A developer received a four-year sentence for activating a "kill switch."
The developer was fired and sought revenge.
The "kill switch" was named after the developer.
The article details the circumstances surrounding the developer's actions.
It highlights the legal consequences of the developer's actions.
